More like flooding

This is part of the ongoing plot of this Marvel universe; it's not over.
Why in the world would they dedicate so much time into teasing this element and NOT have it be important in the Jessica Jones story? It makes no sense and it brings so much attention to itself. And merely teasing it for another property in the future without having any relevance in the current story you're telling is outright lazy. Even with Madame Gao in Daredevil served a purpose within THOSE seasons of the story. Off-handed references are one thing, but making HUGE plot points about characters that are in no way ever related again to the rest of the season or storyline despite the narrative investing huge chunks of time to these elements is just so haphazardly written.
Sort of covered, sort of set up for the next season to discuss
No. That's not a good excuse. And I don't see how it's "sort of covered", especially since her and Tricia BLAZE right past it into the jarring superhero costume stage. Saying "they can answer it later" is absolute poor writing, especially when her powers are such a centerpoint of the story (including her and Kilgrave's relationship to one another with their powers) and are so ill defined.
I believe the assumption is the her immune system fought him off
Why then? Is Kilgrave's power bacteria based? Why did she become free of it after killing Luke's wife? Is it emotional based? Psychological? Did she have to be in the right head space to "heal" herself? Do you see what I mean? And just saying "oh, it's superhero stuff, just role with it" doesn't work when the showmakers want me to take the story seriously. If this was something like The Flash that prides itself on producing the fantastical and weirder side of speculative fiction live-action superhero shows, then being broad concerning the power settings is one thing, but to take a story that features a recovering support group who committed terrible actions, horrific scenes of gore, discussions of rape and abuse, kidnapping, murder, violence, harsh language, ABORTION (which they mishandled as poorly as a show could by making the aborted fetus a POWER-UP FOR THE SUPERVILLAIN), and other adult elements, and then say "yeah, well, we kinda just have the powers work however we need them to in a scene" is so removed of substance it collapses in on itself. They wanted a serious tone with serious subject matter? Fine by me. But they have to stick with their own parameters.
A vast majority of your problems with this show seem to be that season 2 hasn't come out yet.
You can't use that as an excuse because neither one of us knows what's in the next season. We can only judge what was presented to us in the first season, and, in my opinion, it's an incredibly huge mixed bag of quality, erring on the side of negative attributes.
How is this rated T?

The original run of Arrested Development is a MASTERPIECE of comedy
If you're looking for a great show LIKE the comedy of Arrested Development, I'd recommend checking out "Smart Guys" (it's an online series).

I respect your opinion, but while the season was fine for any other comedy show, it was (in my opinion) incredibly disappointing as the new season for Arrested Development. It doesn't help that they removed the best part of the show to accommodate schedule issues - the family dynamic.

How the Hell did she get that information? Why is it relevant to her? Why was she even interested in keeping it with the info about Kilgrave? If we're talking about the USB's connection across shows, how the Hell does it go from having plot relevant data to Kilgrave to having plot relevant data to Luke? We're Luke and Kilgrave connected BEFORE Reva's death? How did she even discover the drive? How did Kilgrave discover she knew about it?

The whole subplot with Luke's wife and the flash drive which has no relevance in the JJ show, how in the world Jessica's bizarre Kilgrave trap would be admissible in court, how she could prove he did it AND that it couldn't be anyone else wth that power, how Jessica even got her powers, why Kilgrave's powers don't affect her anymore yet affect others who have been around him longer, etc.
Why did Kilgrave want her to do that and get the flash drive?
No, but everything in a season should be relevant to that particular story being told, like Madame Gao's involvement in Daredevil.
I'm not looking for perfect science (which is a straw man argument), I'm looking for consistent plot which doesn't leave dumptruck sized plot holes big enough to drive through.
Yeah, that's not point. My argument is why in the world they'd focus such a huge chunk of Jessica Jones on Luke's wife's flash drive and never address it until the Luke Cage series
How? Weren't his parents exposed to his control for FAR longer? Why suddenly after killing Luke's wife?

But why have it in Jessica Jones if it's not going to be apart of the plot? With Madame Gao in Daredevil, she at least had her purpose in THAT show's narrative of being one of Fisk's associates trying to help take over Hell's Kitchen.
What was the purpose of the flash drive? What's the purpose of introducing that? It has no pay off! Especially since it's tied to Kilgrave, Jessica, AND Luke and none of them seem talk about it ever again.

No, I don't think you understand. In the flashbacks of the show and the entire basis of their original relationship, Kilgrave is literally controlling Jessica and then the reasons why she suddenly is able to break free from that are never addressed, ever. It's bad storytelling, it's a lazy narrative thread that is never solved, and frankly, if they really wanted to have the "controlling Jessica through threats of manipulation, while he literally controlled everyone else" type of storyline, they needed to do that with the before and after portions of the story.
This is just confusing and unnecessarily so. That is just poor writing
Man, I did not like those first two seasons of breaking bad, not to mention the characters of Walt Junior and Marie.
No, it wasn't

Charlie Cox is brilliant as Matt Murdock. He has such a layered performance, and that shows so expertly written. The only thing I wish is that they should've stuck with the original reason why stick left from the contacts, rather than being emotionally attached to Matt as it would've made for a much more harsher departure from Matt's life.

I thought the side stories were terrible. Between the actor who played nuke becoming a progressively worse actor as a series one on, to that unbearable kilgrave support group, subplots like what Luke's wife had on the flash drive or why Jessica was able to resist the mind control being totally swept under the rug and unanswered.
Except, he was controlling her Directly. She just somehow manages to magically not be affected anymore because Plot.

I personally thought that the storyline could've been so much more interesting if it actually dealt in the concept of free will, choice, and acceptance, but really screwed up the landing. And the Jigsaw trap she had for Kilgrave? Oh, my god that was terrible. How would any of that be admissible in court? Or better yet, even if she proves kill grave has that power, how can she prove beyond a shadow of the doubt that he's the only one with that power?
The show is just so incredibly off kilter in execution in writing, that it's absolutely painful. They even tip toe past really interesting ideas concerning Jessica actually accepting Kilgrave's relationship to and extent. I don't even get me started on how Jessica basically used Hope as a surrogate for her own vengeance, let other people die, and only decide to kill when it was beneficial for her. And yet, the show never goes into any of those interesting areas. It's infuriating

Oh, stop. I liked the show and Jones in the role. It wasn't a great series but it was fine, especially the drunken master fight.
If anything, I really didn't like Jessica Jones out of all the Netflix marvel TV series. The first couple of episodes established a great crime noir feeling, but then it went off the deep end. I cannot fathom why in the world the show would treat abortion with such lack of care for understanding for either side of the debate and make it just a power up for the villain. The acting gets screwy, Jessica's motivations make absolutely no sense towards the end of the series, plot lines like why Luke's wife had that flash drive or what was on it or how Jessica was even able to brake away from Kilgrave are never explained, and so many of the side characters, like that annoying "Kilgrave support group" that goes nowhere, drag the show down to an absolute screeching halt. I don't know why iron fist get so much crap, admittedly it does need some criticism and places, and yet Jessica Jones gets off Scott free
I didn't know there was this much poetry in the whole galaxy.
I'm just a simple man trying to spin my way across the galaxy.
I think they might even have a Spiderman cameo in there!
Only if you say "no homo" when you cuddle afterwards.

But the entire point of the argument stems from Peter's direct confrontation with the smugglers, and the escalation therein, risking hundreds, if not thousands of lives of innocents.
How is he supposed to know that would have led to the escalation? Not to mention that Peter's M.O. is "with great power, there must also come great responsibility". If Peter sees something wrong and he has the power to right that wrong, he has the obligation to do so, regardless of the consequences. It's what Tony had even done in the Iron Man movies, Age of Ultron, and Civil War.
And it's a lot more direct than the collateral damage that happens in some of the previous missions.
I side with Captain America in this case. If you let what you failed to do keep you from action, next time, you might be choked by hesitation, and maybe NO ONE will be saved.
Smugglers, by their nature, operate in secret. And if Peter hadn't exposed them, then nobody would have been hurt.
That's a stretch. Exposing them could have caused them to scatter. However, it also seems like Peter handled the smugglers pretty easily, with only the Vulture appearing out from a container to cause devastation. Also, Tony is an enormous hypocrite. He took it upon himself to kill the terrorists from the first Iron Man film instead of relying on the U.S. military to do their job they risk their lives for because, as a character flaw, he thinks he knows better than everyone else.

If you think about it, Tony is saying that to precisely because he made that mistake and doesnt want it repeated - its not moral high ground, its experience.
Every time he has tried to control other peoples' behavior, it's backfired in his face. His M.O. is to preach at others about he knows better only to be proven wrong (as a weapons manufacturer in Iron Man, his congressional monolog in Iron Man 2, taunting the Mandarin in Iron Man 3, creating Ultron in Age of Ultron, forcing everyone to accept the Sokovia Accords in Civil War. If I was Peter, I'd be pissed that this son of a bitch was chastising me for risking my life to save other people when that's the purpose of heroes (as the Avengers learned in Age of Ultron).
Tony is also a rich adult that can actually fix a ton of his messes, unlike some kid in spandex.
Who's naturally stronger than him who could take on Cap in a hand-to-hand fight without Tony's fancy AI helping him, and who was smart enough to manufacture his own webbing.
Peter's philosophy is "great power, great responsibility." That means correcting a wrong being done, regardless of the consequences if you have the power to change something.
spidey is doing heroics in a world with dozens of far more experienced heroes.
So what? That's what Tony was doing when he decided that instead of relying on the U.S. government to take down the 10 Rings in Iron Man 1, he put it upon himself to do so. Tony's philosophy here (at least what we can see so far) is "do what I say, not what I do." He's a hypocrite and what's worse is that he's placed others in danger by hindering Peter's ability to fight crime.
I'm the dude playing the dude disguised as another dude!
Well, you wouldn't download a car

I still don't get how he can take the moral high ground of "you can't just save people and do what you think is right just because you have the power to do so" when he himself literally builds a suit of tank armor and kills terrorists in his first film.
I REALLY hope the explanation is better than what we're given in the trailers.

That was....kind of disappointing. None of the jokes were really gelling for me. I liked some of the character moments, but I still have a big sticking point with how much they seem to be cramming in Tony into this film, especially since I really can't see how he's giving Peter grief for putting his life in danger for others when THAT'S EXACTLY WHAT HE DOES IN EVERY FILM. I'm not really gelling with Vulture in this movie.
I know these are just small initial impressions, but it's not really helping the fact that I'm not totally onboard for this movie, and I LOVE Spider-man (favorite superhero and one of my favorite fictional characters ever).

Okay. I do enjoy superhero stories, but I wouldn't consider myself biased towards them as I only like ones that are told well.
For example how is Iron Fist not terrible?
I didn't say it was great or even good. For myself, I think it's competent enough not to be bad, but not interesting enough to be good. Although I feel it's a bit mediocre, that doesn't immediately translate to it being considered "bad" (once again, for myself). I'm probably never going to watch the series again, but I'm not mad that I did. It didn't leave me angry like Jessica Jones did after watching it.
I get that DD is "fighting for actual justice" but I just think that's kinda lame. I prefer the Punisher's approach.
Okay. I think it's a great take on the superhero storyline, especially with a character who's torn between his vigilante approach, his legitimate job as a lawyer, his suppressed love of violence, and his Catholic teachings. The Punisher is a good character in the show, but his way is anarchy and destruction with wanton killing. The moment where Frank is about to execute a completely innocent man who was framed for being the Blacksmith showcases that his form of a vendetta goes through no process besides his own, so he's even more likely to screw up on a personal level.
I don't expect you to agree but that's my take on it at least.
I do respect that point of view, even though I don't personally agree with it.

Nah, I consider it a series. Too long for a mini-series, in my eyes.
"You can fly?!"

It's similar to the way that good sci-fi like Star Trek uses space exploration as a backdrop for more serious issues.
Yeah, those stories CAN be about that, but they can also be fables, mythological tales, avatars for points of view on justice, etc. Kraven's Last Hunt, House of M, The Infinity Gauntlet. All of those stories, and much more, are about telling these myths of heroes simply beyond having domestic issues with a layer of people being able to move things with their mind, or shoot lazers from their eyes.
As a side-note, I did not like Jessica Jones. It began with promise, but the longer it went on, the more unfocused and unhinged the story became with some really spotty writing and acting (outside of Jessica, Luke, and Kilgrave).
(at least once it developed in the 70s-80s past the pulp-fiction dime novels that started it).
The golden age of comics is, once again, that's more mythological and 'pure' in storytelling and akin to Beowulf and Samson. There are still great stories in there, such as Spider-man's origin story which is one of the most wholly complete and satisfying superhero tales to this date full of character, pathos, and emotional depth.

Anyone who appreciates comics for the true storytelling power of that medium should be blown away by shows like Legion that take full advantage of everything a video medium has to offer.
As someone who is a fan of superhero comic book stories, not everything needs to cohere to a specific look or feel for an adaptation. The show is great and I certainly like it the visuals. I just wish they took more time with the antagonists and supporting characters of the show.
I'd say keep going with it. It's rewarding the more layers you experience and reflect on with each episode.

Other comic nerds aren't very interested because it's not squarely in the superhero genre,
I'm a comic book nerd and love it. It's a different interpretation of the material with different sensibilities. It's not what I would think is the best/favorite superhero show on right now (for me, it's Daredevil), but it is a near close-second.

I don't think Daredevil deserves to be out next to Arrow.
First two seasons of Arrow are pretty damn good, some minor quibbles here and there notwithstanding. Recent years haven't exactly been the most kind to it, but I think it refound some of its lost footing.

I liked the action scenes but the acting is pretty mediocre.
Okay. I disagree here. Everyone from Charlie Cox, Deborah Ann Woll, Elodie Yung, Vincent D'Onofrio, Elden Hensen, and the rest of the cast are fantastic.
DD is just good, not great. Not complete garbage like Iron Fist though.
I think it's superb, in my opinion. Iron fist is....alright. It starts off so incredibly bland but does start ramping up after about 3 or 4 episodes in. Not terrible (that's reserved for something like season 3 of Arrow).
I think The Punisher with Jon Bernthal might be cool though. He made DD look like a little pussy.
I think that's the part of season 2 of DD so many people miss out on. DD is fighting for actual justice, not personal vendettas. The courts and systems of balances that keep everything in line without corruption, and it's easy to cut loose and say "forget about the consequences" with Punisher, but it's not that easy. The rooftop argument is a clear indication of how differently these men see the world and their complex counter-points with one another.

I disagree with this. I would say that Legion is the best FILMED superhero show, but in terms of character depth, narrative, pacing, and antagonists, I'd say that Daredevil is still the #1 show, for myself anyway.
I enjoy the Hell out of Legion as well.

Okay. Outside of that amazing Pilot episode, I wouldn't consider the series worth watching. However, I absolutely respect that point of view you have. It's a well shot show with great gore effects, but I just want to see more character depth and story than either the show or its comic counterpart currently have.
